doc.title: phylip

description.text: PHYLIP is a package of programs for inferring phylogenies.

doc.reference: Felsenstein, J. 1993. PHYLIP (Phylogeny Inference Package) version 3.5c. Distributed by the author. Department of Genetics, University of Washington, Seattle.
Felsenstein, J. 1989. PHYLIP -- Phylogeny Inference Package (Version 3.2). Cladistics 5: 164-166.

comment.text: This program implements the Neighbor-Joining method of Saitou and Nei (1987) and the UPGMA method of clustering.

NEIGHBOR constructs a tree by successive clustering of lineages, setting branch lengths as the lineages join. The tree is not rearranged thereafter. The tree does not assume an evolutionary clock, so that it is in effect an unrooted tree.

fieldset.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Give a file containing a distance matrix obtained by distance matrix programs like protdist or dnadist

xhtml:div.label: Randomize (jumble) input order (J) Yes No

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: Random number seed for jumble (must be odd)
Analyze multiple data sets (M) Yes No

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: How many data sets

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: Random number seed for multiple dataset (must be odd)
Compute a consensus tree Yes No

Print out tree (3)?
Yes No
Tells the program to print a semi-graphical picture of the tree in the outfile.

Write out trees onto tree file (4)?
Yes No
Tells the program to save the tree in a treefile (a standard representation of trees where the tree is specified by a nested pairs of parentheses, enclosing names and separated by commas).
Print out the data at start of run (1) Yes No

Outgroup species (default, use as outgroup species 1) (O)?
The O (Outgroup) option specifies which species is to have the root of the tree be on the line leading to it.
For example, if the outgroup is a species "Mouse" then the root of the tree will be placed in the middle of the branch which is connected to this species, with Mouse branching off on one side of the root and the lineage leading to the rest of the tree on the other.
This option is toggle on by choosing the number of the outgroup (the species being taken in the numerical order that they occur in the input file).
Outgroup-rooting will not be attempted if it is a user-defined tree, despite your invoking the option.
When it is used, the tree as printed out is still listed as being an unrooted tree, though the outgroup is connected to the bottommost node so that it is easy to visually convert the tree into rooted form.
Matrix format Square Lower-triangular (L) Upper-triangular (R)

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Tells the program to print a semi-graphical picture of the tree in the outfile.
Tells the program to save the tree in a treefile (a standard representation of trees where the tree is specified by a nested pairs of parentheses, enclosing names and separated by commas).
The O (Outgroup) option specifies which species is to have the root of the tree be on the line leading to it.

For example, if the outgroup is a species "Mouse" then the root of the tree will be placed in the middle of the branch which is connected to this species, with Mouse branching off on one side of the root and the lineage leading to the rest of the tree on the other.
This option is toggle on by choosing the number of the outgroup (the species being taken in the numerical order that they occur in the input file).
Outgroup-rooting will not be attempted if it is a user-defined tree, despite your invoking the option.

When it is used, the tree as printed out is still listed as being an unrooted tree, though the outgroup is connected to the bottommost node so that it is easy to visually convert the tree into rooted form.

format.code: ($value)? " && cp infile neighbor.infile && cp neighbor.outtree intree && consense <consense.params && mv outtree consense.outtree && mv outfile consense.outfile" : ""
("" , " && cp infile neighbor.infile && cp neighbor.outtree intree && consense <consense.params && mv outtree consense.outtree && mv outfile consense.outfile")[ value ]

parameter.name: outgroup
parameter.prompt: Outgroup species (default, use as outgroup species 1) (O)

format.code: ( "" , "O\n" +str( value )+ "\n" )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

message.text: Please enter a value greater than 0

comment.text: The O (Outgroup) option specifies which species is to have the root of the tree be on the line leading to it.

For example, if the outgroup is a species "Mouse" then the root of the tree will be placed in the middle of the branch which is connected to this species, with Mouse branching off on one side of the root and the lineage leading to the rest of the tree on the other.
This option is toggle on by choosing the number of the outgroup (the species being taken in the numerical order that they occur in the input file).
Outgroup-rooting will not be attempted if it is a user-defined tree, despite your invoking the option.

When it is used, the tree as printed out is still listed as being an unrooted tree, though the outgroup is connected to the bottommost node so that it is easy to visually convert the tree into rooted form.

interface.label:
Outgroup species (default, use as outgroup species 1) (O)?
The O (Outgroup) option specifies which species is to have the root of the tree be on the line leading to it.
For example, if the outgroup is a species "Mouse" then the root of the tree will be placed in the middle of the branch which is connected to this species, with Mouse branching off on one side of the root and the lineage leading to the rest of the tree on the other.
This option is toggle on by choosing the number of the outgroup (the species being taken in the numerical order that they occur in the input file).
Outgroup-rooting will not be attempted if it is a user-defined tree, despite your invoking the option.
When it is used, the tree as printed out is still listed as being an unrooted tree, though the outgroup is connected to the bottommost node so that it is easy to visually convert the tree into rooted form.

For example, if the outgroup is a species "Mouse" then the root of the tree will be placed in the middle of the branch which is connected to this species, with Mouse branching off on one side of the root and the lineage leading to the rest of the tree on the other.
This option is toggle on by choosing the number of the outgroup (the species being taken in the numerical order that they occur in the input file).
Outgroup-rooting will not be attempted if it is a user-defined tree, despite your invoking the option.

When it is used, the tree as printed out is still listed as being an unrooted tree, though the outgroup is connected to the bottommost node so that it is easy to visually convert the tree into rooted form.
